title: Oregon Ducks coach Dan Lanning clarifies changes he would make to College Football Playoff
description: Oregon Ducks coach Dan Lanning didn't hesitate when addressing thw biggest issues with the College Football Playoff. The Ducks advanced to next weekend's semifinal New Year's Day.
fullText:
Oregon Ducks coach Dan Lanning clarifies changes he would make to College Football Playoff originally appeared on The Sporting News. Add The Sporting News as a Preferred Source by clicking here.

The Oregon Ducks are one of two remaining Big Ten teams left in the College Football Playoff this postseason.

A 23-0 win against the Texas Tech Red Raiders Thursday sees them advance to the Peach Bowl against the Indiana Hoosiers next Friday with a possibility of a national title berth at their disposal in under three weeks should they keep winning.

As much as coach Dan Lanning was jubilant by the fact his team, which missed out on consecutive Big Ten title berths last month, can still play, he told reporters in Miami, Fla., following the game that the CFP format should still undergo needed adjustments.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs not the same bowl experience anymore when you‚Äôre talking about the Playoff," Lanning said. "Our guys didn‚Äôt leave the hotel, they had the mindset that we‚Äôll celebrate when this thing‚Äôs all over with, and they were really focused."

The Ducks' focus, though, could serve as a hindrance as Lanning suggests bowl games are treated differently than, say, a decade ago.

"It‚Äôs not because we wanted to go play in Lubbock, I certainly didn‚Äôt, I‚Äôm glad we played in Miami, it was good prep for us," Lanning said. "But, you know, last year, a very similar situation for us, I felt like that game should‚Äôve been played in Eugene. There‚Äôs a lot of people who do playoffs, and I feel like the playoffs have looked a certain way for a long time, and we‚Äôre trying to serve two purposes here.‚Äù

Whether Lanning's comments will continue to draw traction remains unclear, but what is clear is that the CFP may have work to do to satisfy everyone moving forward.

title: SWEET REVENGE: Ole Miss upsets Georgia to advance to CFP Semifinals
description: Ole Miss improves to 13-1 and moves on to play Miami in the Fiesta Bowl
fullText:
Trinidad Chambliss and Ole Miss are now the biggest story in college football after an upset of No. 3 Georgia in the Sugar Bowl to advance to the College Football Playoff semifinals.

The No. 6 Rebels (13-1) overcame a 21-12 halftime deficit with some unbelievable play from Chambliss and a clutch field goal from Lucas Carneiro in the final seconds of the game to win, 39-34. Chambliss went 30/46 passing for 362 yards and two touchdowns as the Rebels used a 20-10 margin in the fourth quarter to put the game on ice.

This is not a game Georgia (12-2) loses entering the fourth quarter with a lead. In fact, it was the first game in 76 tries that a team defeated the Bulldogs when it had the lead going into the fourth quarter. SEVENTY SIX FOLKS THATS SPECIAL.

There will probably be some children conceived in Mississippi tonight who will be named Lucas. The sophomore placekicker Carneiro converted a 47-yard field goal with six seconds remaining to make it 37-34, but he set the Sugar Bowl record for longest field goal twice in the first quarter with a 55-yard kick then a 56-yarder shortly after to set and reset the record.

The Ole Miss defense held Georgia to 343 offensive yards including 124 rushing yards at only a 3.4 yards per attempt average. This is one of the big differences from the first version of this game with the defense stalling Georgia when it mattered most and holding Gunnar Stockton to just over 200 yards passing.

Kewan Lacy led all rushers for the Rebels with 98 yards and two touchdowns. Lacy had what seemed to be a gamechanging fumble in the first half that was returned for a Georgia touchdown, but the sophomore RB just seemed to get stronger as the game went on. The determination of this team and the mental toughness shone through the most mounting a comeback against one of the most talented teams in the country.

From the wide receiver room, Trey Wallace led the way with nine catches for 156 yards and a touchdown. De‚ÄôZhaun Stribling also flexed on the shorthanded Bulldog secondary with seven catches for 122 yards.

Truly, this Thursday night was one of the biggest wins in Ole Miss football history. A seventh Sugar Bowl championship second best all time for the Rebels is just some additional icing on the cake.

It‚Äôs now one week until a showdown with No. 10 Miami in the Fiesta Bowl in Glendale, Ariz. HOTTY DAMN TODDY CHEERS!

title: 2 Up, 2 Down: Sunderland Stand Firm To Draw With Man City
description: The Lads played out a 0-0 with Pep Guardiola‚Äôs side on New Year‚Äôs Day. What did our writers make of the game?
fullText:
Mayenda was absolutely phenomenal, playing like a player who wants to prove a point and play more minutes in the best league in the world.

Big, strong, fast, fleet-footed and wonderful. I‚Äôll have his start every game for the rest of his life.

He‚Äôs gone from ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs finished, he doesn‚Äôt need a contract‚Äù to prime Roberto Carlos in a game!

I take back the lack of faith from the Leeds match. I‚Äôm sorry.

This is tough, so I‚Äôm going to go for people selling their tickets to City fans in the concourse.

Why would you do this? There were so many there. You‚Äôre mental!

Less of this coldness ‚Äî I‚Äôm already dying of a chest infection.

I must admit to having a bit of trepidation before the game but the atmosphere at the start and the way we went toe to toe with City was uplifting and very encouraging.

Everyone was up for it ‚Äî hard work and no little skill. What a battling point. Superb!

Everyone deserves a mention but my man of the match was Alderete.

He fought for every ball and put his body on the line. Unbelievable!

I lost count of the number of times they killed the atmosphere and flow of the game by going down and feigning injury.

I wish referees would see this for what it is: cheating ‚Äî or bring in the rugby rule where trainers can come on the pitch but allow play to continue.

Not perfect, but it would be a start in tackling this gamesmanship.

My neutral friend at the match said he was the most inconsistent he‚Äôd seen.

My mate is a Bolton fan and despite what we think, he said the standard in League One is better than we saw last night.

Thankfully, it didn‚Äôt spoil a great performance.

Manchester City were on a run of eight victories coming into this fixture ‚Äî and one of those was against us at the Etihad Stadium, so we know what this opponent is capable of.

None of the home players could be faulted. The defence and midfield were outstanding whilst we restricted City to just four shots on target.

We‚Äôve gone ten Premier League games without defeat at home and this outstanding point was gained with seven players out ‚Äî six at AFCON and Dan Ballard, who also missed out against Leeds United.

Many have remarked on how this team likes to defend, and we‚Äôve earned seven clean sheets so far ‚Äî including three on our travels.

Erling Haaland was very effectively shackled by Nordi Mukiele but we also chose players with attacking intent, with Eliezer Mayenda, Brian Brobbey and Simon Adingra starting. We also had four shots on target then brought on Wilson Isidor and Romaine Mundle later in the game.

Bearing in mind that just over a year ago, we lost at Stoke City, the plan has been executed to perfection, with great recruitment. We‚Äôre now an established Premier League side.

As mentioned, it is very hard to fault any of the players but I felt that at crucial moments we lacked coolness and calm in front of goal ‚Äî especially the chances for Brobbey, Mundle and Adingra.

This argues for some attacking recruitment in the winter transfer window; I still feel we need a wily ‚Äúfox in the box‚Äù who can hit the back of the net but can also pass on his experience to the younger strikers.

It would be unconstructive to try to pick any other faults after another outstanding home performance, but there‚Äôs been a huge turnover of players in the past year and over the next couple of weeks, we may see some more players who were crucial to our progress in that period departing.

It could be ‚Äúfarewell‚Äù to Dan Neil, Aji Alese and others ‚Äî adding to Patrick Roberts, Jobe and Tommy Watson.

Clearing the decks and balancing the books is very important in business terms.

That was one of the most gritty points we‚Äôll get this season and from one to eleven (plus our substitutes) the Lads were all massive.

The defence faced up to everything that was thrown at them and got a well-deserved share of the points.

A special mention for Nordi Mukiele, who showed how to outmuscle Erling Haaland. He was my man of the match, but there were a lot of contenders.

I was chuffed for Mayenda as he‚Äôs made a great claim for a continued run on the right ‚Äî during the AFCON period and maybe beyond.

His pace, aggression and ability to run at defenders with the ball gave us extra options and to hear his song chanted time and again was fantastic.

Hopefully he has his confidence back and can really contribute.

The chances we created have been converted in other games and to miss the chance to nick a narrow win against City leaves me with a similar feeling to the Liverpool away game.

A point is great though ‚Äî so we take it and move on.

The decisions made by the man in black left a lot to be desired but that‚Äôs a common occurrence.

I honestly thought we‚Äôd get better officials at this level but it seems they perform poorly at all levels.

It didn‚Äôt ruin the game but it didn‚Äôt help us. Better luck next time, hopefully!

Hands up everyone who thought our unbeaten home record would fall?

I‚Äôll admit I was one, not only because after the Leeds game I thought we were missing Dan Ballard, Reinildo and Noah Sadiki¬†‚Äî which isn‚Äôt a slight on the players who‚Äôve come in ‚Äî but also because we were up against the dominant force in the Premier League over the last ten to fifteen years, and a team who after a shaky time last season have looked more like their old selves in the past couple of months.

We‚Äôve seen off Arsenal at home; we‚Äôve seen off ‚Äúthe visitors‚Äù and now we‚Äôve seen off the machine that is Manchester City. Who else is out there?

I think he has a lot in his locker for a young striker and last season in the Championship, he worked hard after a bright opening to the campaign, a bit of a indifferent period after injury and then came on strong in the second half of the year to play a significant part in our promotion.

As we went into this season, I felt that if there was one player in our ranks from the Championship squad who could make an impact in the Premier League, it was him.

I think he‚Äôs been a bit unlucky not to get more chances so far with the form of Wilson Isidor and Brian Brobbey, but we looked more balanced and carried more of an attacking threat with him in our ranks.

I hope he keeps his place and gets a run in the side, as he has more to offer.

This match summed up why we are were we are and not fighting a relegation battle.

Unlimited commitment from everyone in a red and white shirt and in the last half hour with City piling forward, we were throwing bodies from all angles in front of the ball.But it wasn‚Äôt all about the Blues and we opened up enough chances to have got a goal ourselves.

City know they got a game from us ‚Äî and there‚Äôll be top teams in the Premier League who won‚Äôt give City as much as a test as we did.

I have no real downs to report and considering how I dreaded it might have turned out you have to be happy with the point, and it wasn‚Äôt a lucky point at that.

It was fully deserved from our view, we are still unbeaten at home going into the New Year and we now have twenty nine points from nineteen games and sit in seventh place halfway through the season.

title: ‚ÄúNever Gonna Leave Ol‚Äô Durham Town‚Ä¶‚Äù
description: John a Wilson feels that now is the time for Sunderland AFC to reaffirm its links with its Durham heartlands!
fullText:
Before I moved away from the North East nearly a quarter of a century ago, one of my favourite places to wander around was Durham, with its beautiful cobbled streets, the castle and cathedral.

In fact, the view from the bridge over the River Wear, with the castle towering on the east bank, is one of the most picturesque and loved scenes in the country (according to a TV programme from the 1990‚Äôs) competing with Arthur‚Äôs Seat in Edinburgh, various Lake District scenes and St. Michael‚Äôs Mount and Tintagel in Cornwall.

Brought up in North Shields and having gone to school in Newcastle‚Äôs West End, I was used to being surrounded by Mag fans, but unlike other stories I‚Äôve heard about school life, there was never ‚Äî to my knowledge ‚Äî violence linked to the team you supported.

Nevertheless, as you can imagine, I got more than enough ear-bashing and taunting from Newcastle supporters, yet there was some solace to be found in my old school‚Äôs slogan, which began: ‚ÄúBy the banks of the silvery Wear, ‚Äòneath proud Durham‚Äôs towered shrine‚Äù, which referred to the burial place of St. Cuthbert ‚Äî the school I attended.

It was always nice to get away from Newcastle City or North Shields, where it would‚Äôve been careless to wear any Sunderland colours or sport the badge on a hat. Durham always felt safe. I was on home territory ‚Äî County Durham and Wearside.

Historically, Sunderland was part of County Durham.

The old county borough was abolished in 1974, with the formation of the new ‚ÄúMetropolitan County of Tyne and Wear‚Äù. The Durham coalfields had strong ties to Sunderland AFC and the Durham Miners‚Äô Association recognises their shared heritage.

Sunderland is often seen as a ‚ÄúDurham Miners‚Äô Club‚Äù and for people in County Durham ‚Äî certainly when I was growing up and before my exile from the North East ‚Äî supporting Sunderland was often the default choice. Whilst some areas leaned towards Newcastle United, it‚Äôs fair to say that Durham generally favoured supporting the Lads.

I‚Äôm not sure when the phrase ‚ÄúDurham Mag‚Äù became a thing, as it certainly sounds like an oxymoron and it wasn‚Äôt a phrase that was coined before the turn of the century.

Some people claim it emerged during the Kevin Keegan years as the visitors experienced a surge in success and media attention which resulted in many younger people in neighbouring County Durham becoming Mag fans. Sunderland‚Äôs fall from grace over the last ten years didn‚Äôt help, as youngsters ‚Äî for the most part ‚Äî want to support a successful or at least a Premier League side.

This whole topic came to the fore after the recent Leeds match, when I decided to stay in Durham after the game.

At check in, the lady at the desk asked if I‚Äôd travelled far. I told her I‚Äôd driven up from Worcestershire but that I‚Äôd only just come from the Sunderland game. She gave me a stern sideways look and jokingly said, ‚ÄúOh, you support them, do you? Boo!‚Äù

I was quite taken aback and informed her that when I used to live locally, most of Durham was red and white ‚Äî we were, after all, on the banks of the Wear.

She retorted that ‚ÄúThese days, it‚Äôs about half-and-half in the area of Sunderland fans and Mags‚Äù.

I‚Äôm not an expert as I never actually lived in County Durham, but some references I‚Äôve seen suggest that it used to be 80% to 20% in favour of supporting the Black Cats, whereas now, it‚Äôs nearer to 50/50. But no wonder the term ‚ÄúDurham Mags‚Äù has such a negative connotation ‚Äî it‚Äôs used pejoratively to imply that these supporters are ‚Äúplastic fans‚Äù or ‚Äúglory hunters‚Äù who lack a genuine local or heritage connection with Newcastle.

Hopefully this season is the start of the fightback and a marker for when school children will want to start supporting the red and whites ‚Äî the dominant team in the North East, derby victors, and a team going places.

A team that isn‚Äôt aligned to dodgy Arab owners, that cares about the community, and has a long-term plan and identity in place.

Happy New Year, and haway me bonnie lads!

title: Where to watch Canada vs. Slovakia live stream, TV channel, start time for 2026 World Juniors hockey quarterfinal game

title: Talking Points: Sunderland‚Äôs Progress Continues Against Manchester City!
description: Ben McKevitt looks at the main stories from Sunderland‚Äôs entertaining New Year‚Äôs Day draw with Pep Guardiola‚Äôs side!
fullText:
Cirkin‚Äôs future at the club has been up for significant debate during the last six months and beyond, with his ability to step up to Premier League level consistently questioned in his absence.

He‚Äôs been thrown in at the deep end to start his Premier League career, and a hot-and-cold performance against Leeds led to a lot of scrutiny, but I think it‚Äôs clear that Cirkin can definitely hold his own at this level.

He was composed, sharp, progressive and incisive down the left, defending valiantly throughout and rarely making an error. It felt like City were targeting the right hand side of our defence ‚Äî which was unsurprising considering how well Cirkin locked down the left channel.

His injuries came at a terrible time and he was unfortunate to have to wait this long for his chance, but he‚Äôs certainly impressing. It was the performance of a player who can hold his own at this level and whilst I don‚Äôt think he‚Äôll displace Reinildo, he can be a more than worthy deputy in this league.

Each week, it‚Äôs becoming clear just how much Brobbey brings to the side when he leads the line.

He provides an incredible outlet when under the cosh ‚Äî especially when facing teams like City who largely dominate possession and heap on the pressure. He gave City‚Äôs defenders an absolute nightmare yesterday, consistently holding the ball up and bringing others into play as we aimed to get an opener.

However, it‚Äôs not just the hold-up play, as he has the pace and power to drive in behind a defence.

A huge opportunity came after he demonstrated unbelievable strength to run off Ruben Dias and going through against Gianluigi Donnarumma.

Unfortunately, Brobbey couldn‚Äôt convert his chance and the game continued at 0-0. I‚Äôd love to see him convert more of these chances as they‚Äôre opportunities you‚Äôd hope your striker would score, but thankfully he contributes massively to the team without the goals.

I think Brobbey‚Äôs ability is especially pronounced when he‚Äôs replaced by Wilson Isidor, who provides less strength and hold-up prowess in the latter stages.

While we often naturally fall back into a more defensive shape towards the end of games, I feel Brobbey‚Äôs absence contributes to the gradual move backwards and Isidor just can‚Äôt replicate his impact at the moment.

Sunderland‚Äôs opportunities largely came in a lively first half in which the Lads pushed City to the absolute limit with a fantastic team performance.

Brobbey‚Äôs massive chance was well manufactured but poorly executed in the end, and Simon Adingra‚Äôs erratic style led to a big opportunity to strike on goal going astray, eventually leading to a sloppy Trai Hume strike which sailed over the bar.

It was Hume who soon found himself in a position of huge promise after Granit Xhaka placed a wonderful cross right onto his head at the penalty spot and whilst he attempted a glancing effort at goal, he couldn‚Äôt manage to use the pace of the ball to guide it on target.

As the game developed, Mayenda had a great chance of his own to get a strike on goal after a characteristically wonderful pick-out by Enzo Le F√©e, which the Spaniard couldn‚Äôt quite get under control.

From here, City began to ramp up the pressure and create opportunities of their own. Savinho, Erling Haaland and Jo≈°kl Gvardiol all came close to breaking through ‚Äî and could‚Äôve done on another day ‚Äî but a combination of fine goalkeeping from Robin Roefs and a mammoth effort from the Lads managed to keep them out.

The chances we carved out are a great sign that we can go toe to toe with one of the best teams in the world and push them to their limit. The game could‚Äôve gone either way on the basis of the chances, and it‚Äôs good to see Le F√©e getting time and space in the middle to improve our creativity.

He‚Äôs a magician in those areas and is somehow doing his own job of creating and inventing while replacing the running of the absent Sadiki ‚Äî amazing work again from the Frenchman.

It was great to see Mayenda back in the starting lineup.

It was an unorthodox shape at times but Mayenda showed that he has the ability to form a good relationship in a two with Brobbey or to provide that creative spark from the right. His play can be a tad erratic but I think that helps him to be unpredictable and dangerous when facing up against defenders.

Our chance creation throughout the season has been our weakest aspect and players who can provide a spark are priceless in this division. We‚Äôve said it from the start of the season ‚Äî he has all the attributes to succeed at this level and he just needs the chance to grow into it.

I‚Äôd love to see him continue getting chances to impress, and I think we‚Äôd benefit from it.

Another Le Bris masterclass, then.

I feel like he‚Äôs somehow still underappreciated across the wider media landscape at the moment ‚Äî perhaps due to his own quiet nature. However, he‚Äôs orchestrating some of the best football we‚Äôve ever experienced at the Stadium of Light and it can‚Äôt keep going unnoticed. The players and the setup at the club are brilliant, but Le Bris brings it all together and stands at the core of everything we do.

The system that Le Bris set up yesterday felt ever-changing and difficult to fully nail down to a formation, regardless of whether we were in or out of possession.

However, he‚Äôd clearly done his homework as it allowed us to exploit weaknesses in behind City‚Äôs backline numerous times across the ninety while retaining good levels of control on the game, and I wasn‚Äôt surprised to see that he was disappointed that we couldn‚Äôt take all three points.

It‚Äôs half way through our first season back, we‚Äôre seventh in the league and disappointed not to be beating Manchester City. Incredible stuff.

The entire defensive unit was incredible. It‚Äôs a sentiment which could likely be duplicated across most performances this season but yesterday was up there with the best.

Omar Alderete and Nordi Mukiele were unbelievable and Erling Haaland may not have a more difficult game this season ‚Äî he was marshalled out of the game, with just a single opportunity on his weaker foot throughout.

Watching the two of them take turns in just going through everything in their way to clear their lines was spectacular, and Alderete‚Äôs tidy feet often provided some great openings to counter.

Having Roefs to rely on must be a dream for a defender and he gave another key performance between the sticks. Instinctive saves and intelligence when playing out from the back allowed us to stay in the game and build into attacks effectively. His influence is priceless and amazing at such a young age.

It must be reiterated that we‚Äôre without several key performers at the back ‚Äî including Dan Ballard and Reinildo.

It‚Äôs an unbelievable feat which has allowed us to earn our tenth consecutive unbeaten game at home. We keep rolling on.

title: Matchday Musings: ‚ÄúNot Tonight, Pep‚Äù: Sunderland Hold City!
description: The mercury reading might‚Äôve plummeted to well below zero by the time the Lads and the Etihad aristocrats kicked off on New Year‚Äôs Day, but after ninety-plus minutes of fast, furious and fascinating football, the Stadium Of Light had warmed up nicely ‚Äî even as 40,000+ headed for the exits and into the icy grip [‚Ä¶]
fullText:
The mercury reading might‚Äôve plummeted to well below zero by the time the Lads and the Etihad aristocrats kicked off on New Year‚Äôs Day, but after ninety-plus minutes of fast, furious and fascinating football, the Stadium Of Light had warmed up nicely ‚Äî even as 40,000+ headed for the exits and into the icy grip of a winter Wearside night.

The outcome? 0-0. The conclusion? Sunderland can play. We can mix it. We can stand firm and we can deliver results from seemingly improbable situations.

Stripped of our AFCON contingent and the injured Dan Ballard, the smart money might‚Äôve been on a routine victory for Pep Guardiola‚Äôs ever-evolving and ruthlessly slick footballing machine.

However, I don‚Äôt think R√©gis Le Bris nor his players believe in the ‚Äúsmart money‚Äù theory ‚Äî just as legendary Australian batsman Don Bradman claimed he didn‚Äôt believe in the law of averages ‚Äî and as Sunderland‚Äôs reshuffled side held firm to deny the visitors a victory (perhaps throwing a spanner into their title works in the process) how could you not feel a sense of overwhelming pride at this side‚Äôs development, ability and commitment to the cause?

My goodness, this really is a team to be proud of.

It‚Äôs a group of players blessed with a unique mixture of skill and steel; of physicality and growing football intelligence, and under the watchful eye of Le Bris, we‚Äôre adding real value to the league, standing firm in the face of any and all challenges ‚Äî and on this occasion, defending our unbeaten home record with incredible ferocity.

After such a superb team display, I could throw some names into the mix and appraise them duly, so I shall.

Dennis Cirkin? Outstanding. The victim of some frankly disgraceful criticism in some quarters, the left back handled the occasion and the opposition superbly, showing composure, positional awareness and no lack of attacking instinct. This was exactly the kind of performance he would‚Äôve hoped for, and Reinildo‚Äôs absence may be less worrisome as a result.

Robin Roefs? Colosssal. He‚Äôs just that good. Simon Adingra? Unbelievably industrious. Brian Brobbey? A handful all evening. Eliezer Mayenda? A real livewire. He played like a man with a point to prove and added some fresh impetus to the red and white attack.

On and on it could go, because each of the lads in red and white did themselves proud on Thursday evening.

Simply put, they weren‚Äôt content to shut up shop and hope for a City off-night. Instead, they took the game to the visitors, made life tough for them and could‚Äôve easily emerged as victors had some of the outstanding chances we created been converted.

City captain Bernardo Silva has form for lamenting occasions on which opposing teams don‚Äôt roll over, sit back and allow his side to dominate ‚Äî so what would he have felt in the aftermath of this outstanding Sunderland display?

Sometimes, it‚Äôs just not your night.

An early City goal being ruled out for offside might not have seemed alarming for Guardiola and his men, but as the game unfolded and Sunderland probed, pressed and chased without mercy, it became clear that this wasn‚Äôt going to be the walkover that many ‚Äî including this writer ‚Äî feared.

Erling Haaland simply wasn‚Äôt able to influence proceedings; Phil Foden was relatively quiet and in the City goal, I didn‚Äôt think Gianluigi Donnarumma was the tower of strength and composure that Ederson used to be, either.

In contrast, the Lads were steadfast in their refusal to be breached.

Even without Ballard, the central defensive partnership of Nordi Mukiele and Omar Alderete was immense and there was no lack of aggression in midfield, either. If this is the kind of result a team affected by absences can achieve, what‚Äôs possible with some January reinforcements and the return of the lads currently representing their countries in Morocco?

In the context of our season, this felt like a huge bonus for Sunderland; the sort of point you grab with both hands, add to the total and reflect on a job very well done.

When Arsenal visited Wearside earlier in the season, we gave them a bit of a shock by rallying from 1-2 down to draw 2-2. To me, this felt even more significant ‚Äî another outstanding display against a world class outfit from a side that you simply can‚Äôt fail to love.

In victory, the players conduct themselves as winners should.

In defeat, there‚Äôs a calm period of reflection and when we shook hands with our opponent after sharing the points on New Year‚Äôs Day, we could allow ourselves a moment to digest the fact that we blunted one of English football‚Äôs finest teams and ensured that we kicked off 2026 on another hugely positive note.

That‚Äôs something to which we can all raise a glass.

Sunderland: Roefs, Hume, Mukiele; Alderete, Cirkin, Geertruida; Xhaka, Mayenda, Le F√©e; Adingra (Mundle 72‚Äô), Brobbey (Isidor 58‚Äô)

Subs Not Used: Patterson, Hjelde, O‚ÄôNien, Jones, Rigg, Neil, Tutierov

Manchester City: Donnarumma, Nunes, Dias; Ake, O‚ÄôReilly (Gvardiol 57‚Äô), Bernardo Silva (Reijnders 85‚Äô); Gonz√°lez (Rodri 46‚Äô), Foden, Cherki; Savinho (Doku 51‚Äô), Haaland

Subs Not Used: Trafford, Heskey, Khusanov, Mukasa, Lewis

title: UAB transfer WR Iverson Hooks to visit Oregon, date TBD
description: With the transfer portal officially opening, UAB standout wide receiver Iverson Hooks has announced his intentions of visiting Oregon.
fullText:
The clock has struck midnight on Jan. 2 on the East Coast, meaning the transfer portal has officially opened.

Over 1,000 names have been entered into the portal, with more surely to come soon. With the opening of the portal comes the search for a new school, with players announcing their schedule of what programs they're visiting.

The Oregon Ducks have been one of the top transfer destinations during head coach Dan Lanning's tenure, with success stories such as safety Dillon Thieneman, defensive tackle Bear Alexander and wide receiver Malik Benson standing out in 2025 alone.

UAB Blazers wide receiver Iverson Hooks, who announced his intentions of entering the portal last week, officially released the seven schools that he'll visit, with the Ducks among them. He has visit dates scheduled for Wisconsin, Indiana, Oklahoma State, LSU and Auburn, with dates for visits to Oregon and Louisville listed as to be announced.

NEWS: UAB standout transfer WR Iverson Hooks is set to visit 7 Schools, his agent @WeGetYouOffers tells @On3Sports

Wisconsin: January 3-4
Indiana: January 4-5
Oklahoma State: January 6-7
LSU: January 7-8
Auburn: January 8-9
Oregon & Louisville: TBAhttps://t.co/RlUbB6Fk7q pic.twitter.com/w2rqBhd28y

‚Äî Hayes Fawcett (@Hayesfawcett3) January 2, 2026

Hooks is a redshirt junior, having spent the first four seasons of his career at UAB. He recorded under 200 receiving yards in both 2023 and 2024, but broke out as the Blazers' leading receiver this season, totaling 927 yards and seven touchdowns on 72 receptions. Despite his standout efforts, UAB finished 4-8.

At 5-foot-10 and 175 pounds, Hooks is a jitterbug out of the slot. He's not a deep threat, as he averaged just 12.9 yards per catch, but he's dangerous with the ball in his hands due to his speed.

The Alabama native is rated as a three-star transfer by 247 Sports, coming in as the No. 40 wide receiver in the portal and No. 159 player overall.

Due to a season-ending injury in which he played in just three games during his redshirt freshman season, Hooks will have two seasons of eligiblity remaining.

Contact/Follow¬†@Ducks_Wire¬†on X (formerly Twitter) and like our page on¬†Facebook¬†to follow ongoing coverage of Oregon Ducks news, notes, and opinions.

This article originally appeared on Ducks Wire: UAB transfer WR Iverson Hooks to visit Oregon, date TBD

title: Ole Miss-Georgia had 1 of the weirdest endings ever: A safety, a free kick, confused stage workers and 9 laterals
description: The Sugar Bowl between Ole Miss and Georgia was a game so nice it ended thrice.
fullText:
A game as good as the Sugar Bowl between Ole Miss and Georgia had to have a wild ending. It ended up having three of them.

In one of the more confusing endings to a football game you will ever see, Ole Miss twice celebrated what it thought was the final play of a breakthrough win in the College Football Playoff, only to be told the game hadn‚Äôt ended.

In both cases, the crew working the stage for the trophy ceremony had already moved it onto the field, then had to awkwardly remove it as the game played on.

The refs REALLY drew this one out üò≠ pic.twitter.com/oDdgVjvjLg

‚Äî Yahoo Sports (@YahooSports) January 2, 2026

The sequence of events worked out like this.

After a frantic drive that saw Ole Miss reach the Georgia 30-yard line in less than a minute, Ole Miss kicker Lucas Carneiro broke a 34-34 tie with a 47-yard field goal. That appeared to be the game-winner, but six seconds were still left on the clock, so Ole Miss had to kick the ball back to Georgia, opening the door for a miracle for the Bulldogs.

Instead, an attempt at a cross-field lateral resulted in the ball bouncing out of bounds, but not without first hitting the pylon. That made it a safety for Ole Miss, putting the Rebels up five points with one second left. Ole Miss had already been celebrating the win, with quarterback Trinidad Chambliss hugging teammates and several non-players and coaches already running onto the field.

The officials restored order and had Georgia make its free kick, which went 10 yards and then was recovered by Bulldogs running back Cash Jones. However, Ole Miss thought that the final second of the game had still passed and celebrated accordingly, giving head coach Pete Golding a Gatorade bath as the ESPN announcers pronounced the game over.

Nope. The officials ruled there was still one second left on the clock ‚Ä¶ and Georgia had the ball at its own 31-yard line. ESPN announcer Sean McDonough said the ending felt ‚Äúexcruciating‚Äù and asked rules expert Matt Austin, ‚ÄúDoes common sense need to prevail here?‚Äù

Austin‚Äôs response. "Well, yes, but we do have rules we have to follow.‚Äù

And so Georgia got its last play, completing one forward pass and nine laterals before quarterback Gunner Stockton was slammed to the ground, 80 yards short of the end zone. The game was over, for real this time.

You can watch the whole thing play out below:

The official play-by-play of that final desperation play:

STOCKTON, Gunner pass short to the left complete for 4 yards to YOUNG, Colbie caught at the UGA35 and advanced to the UGA35 lateral to JONES, Cash for 1 yard to the UGA36 lateral to LUCKIE, Lawson for -3 yards to the UGA33 lateral to JONES, Cash for 5 yards to the UGA38 lateral to YOUNG, Colbie for -7 yards to the UGA31 lateral to YOUNG, Colbie for -5 yards to the UGA26 lateral to LUCKIE, Lawson for 7 yards to the UGA33 lateral to JONES, Cash for 13 yards to the UGA46 lateral to YOUNG, Colbie for -14 yards to the UGA32 lateral to LUCKIE, Lawson for 0 yards to the UGA32 lateral to BELL, Dillon for -11 yards to the UGA21 lateral to MADDOX, Adrian for -2 yards to the UGA19 (PERKINS, Suntarine;JONES, Andrew), clock 00:00.

This could have become even more chaotic, but the end result was what everyone expected after Carneiro made his kick. Ole Miss will advance to the semifinal of the College Football Playoff and face Miami. Georgia‚Äôs season is over. Rebels head coach Pete Golding is $500,000 richer. So is former head coach Lane Kiffin.

And we saw firsthand just how far officials will go to end a game by the book.

title: India‚Äôs ITC Sheds $7 Billion as ‚ÄòTax Shock‚Äô Triggers Rating Cuts
description: India‚Äôs largest cigarette maker ITC Ltd. wiped out about $7 billion in market value after a government tax hike on tobacco products triggered a wave of brokerage downgrades.
fullText: MarketsBy Alex Gabriel SimonSaveIndia‚Äôs largest cigarette maker ITC Ltd. wiped out about $7 billion in market value after a government tax hike on tobacco products triggered a wave of brokerage downgrades. Shares of the firm fell as much as 5.1% on Friday, touching the lowest level since February 2023 and extending a near 10% slide from the previous session. At least 11 brokerages, including Goldman Sachs Group Inc., JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Morgan Stanley, downgraded the stock after the government hiked excise duty on cigarettes this week.

title: Human State Infrastructure for Modern Systems
description: Synheart introduces a new Human State Infrastructure, designed to enable modern systems to represent and interact with human state through standardized, on-device interfaces.
fullText:
Modern software systems understand what users do, but not how users feel or function.

Clicks, taps, ratings, and text inputs have become the dominant form of ‚Äúhuman feedback.‚Äù These signals are explicit, sparse, and often arrive too late to be useful. Meanwhile, humans continuously emit rich physiological and behavioral signals that reveal stress, focus, fatigue, calm, and engagement ‚Äî signals that today‚Äôs systems largely ignore.

Today, we‚Äôre introducing Synheart ‚Äî a privacy-preserving Human State Interface (HSI) infrastructure that enables modern systems to understand human state in real time, ethically, locally, and through standardized representations.

Most human‚Äìcomputer interaction systems rely on:

Yet human state is always present.

Stress, focus, emotional load, and behavioral patterns continuously influence decision-making and performance ‚Äî but modern systems have no native way to perceive or represent them.

Synheart introduces a new primitive for computing systems: human state.

Instead of collecting raw biosignals or subjective feedback, Synheart transforms physiological signals (such as heart-rate-derived features) and digital behavior into structured, machine-readable human state outputs.

These outputs describe what the human system is doing internally ‚Äî not just what the user clicks.

Human state becomes a first-class signal, alongside time, location, and interaction.

At the core of Synheart is the Human State Interface (HSI).

HSI is a foundational interface standard for representing and exchanging human state across independent systems ‚Äî similar in role to GPS coordinates or HTTP responses.

HSI does not transmit raw biosignals.

It represents interpreted human state in a safe, structured form.

This allows systems to reason about human state without ever accessing sensitive biometric data.

Synheart is built with privacy as a non-negotiable constraint.

Users retain control. Developers get insight. Systems remain ethical.

To support a diverse wearable ecosystem, we‚Äôve introduced Synheart Wear a while ago.

Synheart Wear is a vendor-agnostic library that reads biosignals from consumer wearables and normalizes them into a unified signal layer.

It abstracts away hardware differences so developers and researchers can focus on human state, not device-specific integrations.

To complement physiological signals, Synheart includes Synheart Behavior ‚Äî a cross-platform SDK for capturing and transforming digital interaction patterns into structured behavioral signals.

Synheart Behavior models how users interact with digital systems ‚Äî such as timing, rhythm, switching, and interaction fragmentation ‚Äî and converts these patterns into numerical behavioral features, without accessing content, text, or personal data.

The SDK abstracts application- and platform-specific interactions into a unified behavioral signal layer, allowing developers and researchers to reason about human behavior, not interface details.

These behavioral signals power downstream systems such as:

Important: Synheart Behavior analyzes interaction dynamics, not what users type, read, or see.

No content inspection. No surveillance. Privacy by design.

Developers can install Synheart Core SDKs directly on device and build applications that adapt to human state in real time.

Synheart is also a research platform.

All specifications, schemas, and whitepapers are publicly available from day one.

We believe human-state-aware computing must be built in the open.

Our goal is not a single product, but an ecosystem where:

We‚Äôre working toward a future where human state is a first-class signal in computing.

Human-state-aware systems begin here.

title: Designing type-safe sync/async mode support in TypeScript
description: I recently added sync/async mode support to Optique, a type-safe CLI parserfor TypeScript.  It turned out to be one of the trickier features I'veimplemented‚Äîthe object() combinator alone needed to compute a combined modefrom all its child parsers, and TypeScript's inference kept hitting edge cases.
fullText:
Ê¥™ Ê∞ëÊÜô (Hong Minhee) @hongminhee@hackers.pub

I recently added sync/async mode support to Optique, a type-safe CLI parser
for TypeScript. It turned out to be one of the trickier features I've
implemented‚Äîthe object() combinator alone needed to compute a combined mode
from all its child parsers, and TypeScript's inference kept hitting edge cases.

Optique is a type-safe, combinatorial CLI parser for TypeScript, inspired by
Haskell's optparse-applicative. Instead of decorators or builder patterns,
you compose small parsers into larger ones using combinators, and TypeScript
infers the result types.

The type inference works through arbitrarily deep compositions‚Äîin most cases,
you don't need explicit type annotations.

Lucas Garron (@lgarronLucas Garron) opened an issue requesting
async support for shell completions. He wanted to provide
Tab-completion suggestions by running shell commands like
git for-each-ref to list branches and tags.

At first, I didn't like the idea. Optique's entire API was synchronous, which
made it simpler to reason about and avoided the ‚Äúasync infection‚Äù problem where
one async function forces everything upstream to become async. I argued that
shell completion should be near-instantaneous, and if you need async data, you
should cache it at startup.

But Lucas pushed back. The filesystem is a database, and many useful
completions inherently require async work‚ÄîGit refs change constantly, and
pre-caching everything at startup doesn't scale for large repos. Fair point.

So, how do you support both sync and async execution modes in a composable
parser library while maintaining type safety?

The fourth requirement is the tricky one. Consider this:

The combined parser should be async because one of its fields is async.
This means we need type-level logic to compute the combined mode.

I explored five different approaches, each with its own trade-offs.

Add a mode type parameter to Parser and use conditional types:

The challenge is computing combined modes:

A variant of Option A, but place the mode parameter first with a default
of "sync":

The default value maintains backward compatibility‚Äîexisting user code keeps
working without changes.

Define completely separate Parser and AsyncParser interfaces with
explicit conversion:

Simpler to understand, but requires code duplication and explicit conversions.

The minimal approach. Only allow suggest() to be async:

This addresses the original use case but doesn't help if async parse() is
ever needed.

Use the technique from fp-ts to simulate Higher-Kinded Types:

The most flexible approach, but with a steep learning curve.

Rather than commit to an approach based on theoretical analysis, I created
a prototype to test how well TypeScript handles the type inference in practice.
I published my findings in the GitHub issue:

Both approaches correctly handle the ‚Äúany async ‚Üí all async‚Äù rule at the
type level. (‚Ä¶) Complex conditional types like
ModeValue<CombineParserModes<T>, ParserResult<TState>> sometimes require
explicit type casting in the implementation. This only affects library
internals. The user-facing API remains clean.

The prototype validated that Option B (explicit mode parameter with default)
would work. I chose it for these reasons:

The CombineModes type computes whether a combined parser should be sync or
async:

This type checks if "async" is present anywhere in the tuple of modes.
If so, the result is "async"; otherwise, it's "sync".

For combinators like object(), I needed to extract modes from parser
objects and combine them:

The type system handles compile-time safety, but the implementation also needs
runtime logic. Each parser has a $mode property that indicates its execution
mode:

Combinators compute their mode at construction time:

Lucas suggested an important refinement during our
discussion. Instead of having run() automatically choose between sync and
async based on the parser mode, he proposed separate functions:

Perhaps run(‚Ä¶) could be automatic, and runSync(‚Ä¶) and runAsync(‚Ä¶) could
enforce that the inferred type matches what is expected.

I applied the same pattern to parse()/parseSync()/parseAsync() and
suggest()/suggestSync()/suggestAsync() in the facade functions.

With the new API, creating an async value parser for Git branches looks
like this:

Notice that parse() returns Promise.resolve() even though it's synchronous.
This is because the ValueParser<"async", T> type requires all methods to use
async signatures. Lucas pointed out this is a minor ergonomic issue. If only
suggest() needs to be async, you still have to wrap parse() in a Promise.

I considered per-method mode granularity (e.g., ValueParser<ParseMode, SuggestMode, T>), but the implementation complexity would multiply
substantially. For now, the workaround is simple enough:

Supporting dual modes added significant complexity to Optique's internals.
Every combinator needed updates:

For example, the object() combinator went from around 100 lines to around
250 lines. The internal implementation uses conditional logic based on the
combined mode:

This duplication is the cost of supporting both modes without runtime overhead
for sync-only use cases.

My initial instinct was to resist async support. Lucas's persistence and
concrete examples changed my mind, but I validated the approach with a
prototype before committing. The prototype revealed practical issues (like
TypeScript inference limits) that pure design analysis would have missed.

Making "sync" the default mode meant existing code continued to work
unchanged. This was a deliberate choice. Breaking changes should require
user action, not break silently.

I chose unified mode (all methods share the same sync/async mode) over
per-method granularity. This means users occasionally write
Promise.resolve() for methods that don't actually need async, but the
alternative was multiplicative complexity in the type system.

The entire design process happened in a public GitHub issue. Lucas, Giuseppe,
and others contributed ideas that shaped the final API. The
runSync()/runAsync() distinction came directly from Lucas's feedback.

This was one of the more challenging features I've implemented in Optique.
TypeScript's type system is powerful enough to encode the ‚Äúany async means all
async‚Äù rule at compile time, but getting there required careful design work and
prototyping.

What made it work: conditional types like ModeValue<M, T> can bridge the gap
between sync and async worlds. You pay for it with implementation complexity,
but the user-facing API stays clean and type-safe.

Optique 0.9.0 with async support is currently in pre-release testing. If
you'd like to try it, check out PR #70 or install the pre-release:

title: Photographing the hidden world of slime mould
description: Meet Barry Webb and his award-winning images of the tiny world of slime mould.
fullText:
Welcome to the world of slime mould.

These images, captured by photographer Barry Webb, provide a close-up view of single-celled slime mould organisms. A view that would not be possible with the naked eye.

Using a high-powered macro lens, and a composite of stills, Barry is able to reveal the tiny structures, which can grow anywhere from forests to deserts.

Barry has won awards for his work, which is mainly focused west of London, including the recent people's choice award in the macro section of the British photography awards.

title: Ukraine fakes commander's death to trick Russia into paying $500k bounty
description: Kyiv deception operation pays off as Moscow intelligence fooled by assassination claims
fullText:
As far as the Russians were concerned, they had got their man.

Denis Kapustin, one of the most prominent anti-Putin Russians fighting on behalf of Ukraine, was reported dead on Dec 27, assassinated by a drone on the southern front.

He had long been hunted by Moscow and the price on his head reflected this: Russian intelligence services had offered $500,000 (¬£370,000) to anyone who killed him.

Russia paid this out after news broke of the successful hit this week. But what Vladimir Putin‚Äôs intelligence services did not know was that they had handed the money directly to Ukraine.

Mr Kapustin, known by his nom de guerre ‚ÄúWhite Rex‚Äù, founded the pro-Ukrainian Russian Volunteer Corps (RDK) in 2022.

The group made headlines in 2023 and 2024 when it carried out cross-border incursions into Russia‚Äôs Belgorod and Kursk regions, humiliating the Russian president and his generals.

His death was first confirmed by the RDK itself. ‚ÄúWe will definitely take revenge, Denis,‚Äù the group said on Telegram. ‚ÄúYour legacy lives on.‚Äù

Yet on New Year‚Äôs Day, in a morale-raising ruse, Mr Kapustin re-emerged ‚Äì alive and unscathed ‚Äì in a video posted by Ukraine‚Äôs military intelligence (HUR).

‚ÄúWelcome back to life,‚Äù Gen Kyrylo Budanov, head of HUR, said with a wry smile. He congratulated Mr Kapustin and his team on a successful operation to deceive their Russian adversaries.

It turns out HUR, along with the RDK, had hatched a plan to fake Mr Kapustin‚Äôs death and claim the $500,000 bounty from Russia for themselves, to be used in Ukraine‚Äôs war effort.

‚ÄúFirst of all, Mr Denis, congratulations on your return to life. That is always a pleasure. I am glad that the money allocated for your assassination was used to support our struggle,‚Äù Gen Budanov added.

Russia‚Äôs FSB and GRU agencies have long been feared for their ruthlessness.

But Ukrainian intelligence, throughout the near four-year war, has consistently proved its ability to outsmart their Russian counterparts, carrying out assassinations of generals and Kremlin officials on Russian soil, orchestrating complex sabotage operations and recruiting Russian agents.

In November, it was reported that Ukraine‚Äôs intelligence services used Russia‚Äôs own agents to accept missions offered openly by the FSB for financial reward and sabotaging its objectives.

In one case, a Ukrainian double-agent accepted a task from a Russia jobs board to build a bomb, which was then handed to a Russian saboteur.

The bomb, however, was made using flour and the Russian agent was captured by Ukraine after it failed to detonate.

Ukraine has also claimed responsibility for assassinations of high-ranking Russian officials, while Kyiv is suspected to have been behind many others.

In April, Yaroslav Moskalik, deputy chief of the main operations directorate of Russia‚Äôs army, was killed by a car bomb on Nesterov Boulevard in the Balashikha suburb of Moscow.

Baza, a Russian media outlet with sources inside law enforcement agencies, said the home-made bomb was strapped to a parked Volkswagen car and detonated remotely when Moskalik, who lived in the neighbourhood, walked past.

A month later, a former Ukrainian politician was shot dead in what appeared to be a professional hit job at the entrance of an exclusive school in Madrid.

Andriy Portnov, a pro-Russian politician who worked as a close aide to the Moscow regime, was dropping off his daughters when an assassin shot him several times.

The shooting took place at the American School of Madrid while other parents were also making the school run.

Most recently, Lt Gen Fanil Sarvarov, 56, head ‚Äçof the Russian army‚Äôs operational training ‚Äçdirectorate, died in an explosion on Dec 22 in Moscow, probably planted by Ukrainian special forces.

The force of the explosion was such that at least seven cars parked nearby also sustained damage

The general worked in the Russian ministry of defence and participated in combat operations in Chechnya, Syria and Ossetia as well as Ukraine.

Among the most striking assassinations was the killing of Lt Gen Igor Kirillov on Dec 17 2024.

The officer, who was in charge of Russia‚Äôs nuclear, chemical and biological weapons, was killed by a remotely detonated device hidden inside an electric scooter.

‚ÄúKirillov was a war criminal and an absolutely legitimate target, as he gave orders to use banned chemical weapons against the Ukrainian military,‚Äù a Ukrainian security source said.

In a daring mission in June 2025 ‚Äì dubbed Operation Spiderweb ‚Äì Ukraine-operated drones destroyed several Russian surveillance aircraft and nuclear-capable bombers, with officials in Kyiv saying this rendered a third of Russia‚Äôs strategic cruise missile carriers useless.

The drones had been smuggled into Russia and assembled, and launched from trucks deep within Russian territory, in another huge victory for Ukraine‚Äôs spies.

Ukraine‚Äôs latest intelligence success means Denis Kapustin, a far-Right extremist and former football hooligan, is inside Ukrainian territory and ‚Äúpreparing to continue carrying out assigned tasks‚Äù, said a Ukrainian commander.

The commander‚Äôs family moved from Moscow to Germany when Mr Kapustin was 17 and he relocated to Ukraine in 2017.

Since 2019, he has been banned from entering the Schengen Area for promoting neo-Nazi ideology.

In the early weeks of Russia‚Äôs full-scale invasion, Mr Kapustin helped set up units that would become Ukraine‚Äôs 3rd Assault Brigade that played a key role in defending Kyiv and later become renowned for its fierce fighting on the eastern front.

Responding to reports of his death, the 3rd Army Corps said: ‚ÄúWe together confronted the common enemy in the battle for Kyiv.‚Äù

It added on Dec 27: ‚ÄúHe perceived [Ukraine] as a place of real resistance and freedom.‚Äù

In August 2022, Mr Kapustin set up the RDK, with the goal of overthrowing Putin to bring ‚Äúpeace to Russia‚Äù. Its stated aim is to end Putin‚Äôs regime of ‚Äúlies, corruption, and lawlessness‚Äù.

It is made up of former Wagner Group recruits, some former FSB agents and civilian volunteers. It is deemed a terrorist organisation by Russia.

Russian courts have twice sentenced Mr Kapustin to life imprisonment in absentia on treason and terrorism charges.

In March 2024, the RDK stormed into Russia alongside other anti-Kremlin militias on tanks and armoured vehicles. It clashed with Russian security services and captured Russian soldiers.

Kyiv has said that while it fights as part of Ukraine‚Äôs military, under its command, the incursions into Russia were not taking place under Kyiv‚Äôs orders.

Since its incursions, the group is either fighting at the front or engaged in cross-border sabotage operations in Russia.

In an interview with The Telegraph in September, an RDK commander known as ‚ÄúWhite‚Äù, a 26-year-old Russian volunteer, described how he joined in order to exact revenge on Putin for invading Ukraine.

‚ÄúWe fight to change something in Russia,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhen the war ends, I will continue fighting until Putin falls.‚Äù

title: A famous motif started out a failure. Now 130, it's become a global fashion flex
description: The famous motif started out a failure. Now 130, it‚Äôs become a global fashion flex
fullText:
The imminent 130th anniversary of the Louis Vuitton monogram is less a birthday and more a demonstration of how powerful two letters can be.

Born in 1896, when the √âpoque was at its most Belle, the superposed initials LV appeared amidst a variety of foliate and geometrical motifs. At first it was not a success. ‚ÄúThe public was initially reticent and demanded the chequered and even the striped canvas, but my father stood firm,‚Äù recalled Gaston-Louis Vuitton of his father Georges Vuitton, son of the founder.

The striped and chequered patterns he mentions refer to previous designs. Every decade or so, Vuitton changed the pattern of the canvas with which it covered its famous, flat-topped trunks. Trianon grey came first in 1858. In 1872, the grey gave way to stripes. The checkerboard Damier pattern came in 1888, and was the first time that the maker‚Äôs name appeared on luggage, with the words ‚ÄúMarque L Vuitton D√©pos√©e‚Äù (which translate as ‚ÄúL Vuitton registered trademark‚Äù) appearing every so often in the checks.

The Damier was intended to scare off counterfeiters. It didn‚Äôt work ‚Äî which leads us to the monogram we know today. If Georges thought that this new design would deter the fakers,¬†a summer stroll along a 21st-century Mediterranean beach, with its itinerant vendors of imposter Louis Vuitton bags, shows just how comprehensively he failed.

Georges Vuitton had inadvertently created one of, if not the, most recognisable hieroglyphs in the history of luxury goods. This was not branding as we know it today; it was more akin to an artist signing a canvas. As well as a hint of the Japonisme, the mania for all things Japanese that gripped France in the late 19th century, the geometric emblems attested to Georges Vuitton‚Äôs fascination with the ogives and spandrels of Gothic architecture. In particular, he was a great admirer of the work of Eug√®ne Viollet-le-Duc, the French architect who revolutionised the study and restoration of medieval architecture.

Viollet-le-Duc‚Äôs reputation may since have faded, but the patterned monogram is known in every corner of the globe. This January, the house will embark on a year-long celebration with the familiar dramatis personae taking to the stage: the Speedy of 1930; the Keepall, also from 1930; the No√©, made for a champagne producer in 1932 to carry five bottles (four upright and the fifth inverted); the Alma, Parisian architecture translated into handbag in 1992; and, finally, the Neverfull of 2007 ‚Äî capable, so Vuitton says, of carrying up to 100 kilogrammes but more usually functioning as a capacious tote.

The bags will appear in different guises throughout the anniversary year. Most striking of the three celebratory capsules is Monogram Origine, a collection of the classics (minus, for some reason, the Keepall), that returns to Georges‚Äôs first pattern but deploys a newly developed coated linen/cotton canvas that comes in its recognisable chocolate-brown Eb√®ne shade as well as a soft rainbow of pastels. All of which provide further proof, if further proof were needed, that at 130 years of age, the famous monogram is as versatile as it is well known.

title: Rain soaks Rose Parade in California and snow squalls hit Midwest and Northeast on first day of 2026
description: Rain poured down on the iconic Rose Parade on Thursday for the first time in 20 years, as flood warnings and evacuation orders in Southern California joined snow squalls and frigid temperatures in the country's midsection to mark the first day of 2026.  Marching bands, floats and throngs of spectators were soaked by one to two inches (2.5 to 5 centimeters) of New Year‚Äôs Day rain at the 137th Rose Parade in Pasadena.  Across the country, in New York City, hats and gloves were as necessary as noisemakers at the city's New Year's Eve ball drop, where temperatures near freezing appeared to be the coldest in 10 years.
fullText:
Rain poured down on the iconic Rose Parade on Thursday for the first time in 20 years, as flood warnings and evacuation orders in Southern California joined snow squalls and frigid temperatures in the country's midsection to mark the first day of 2026.

Marching bands, floats and throngs of spectators were soaked by one to two inches (2.5 to 5 centimeters) of New Year‚Äôs Day rain at the 137th Rose Parade in Pasadena. The mercury stood at a chilly 58 degrees Fahrenheit (14.4 degrees Celsius) at the 8 a.m. start of the parade.

Across the country, in New York City, hats and gloves were as necessary as noisemakers at the city's New Year's Eve ball drop, where temperatures near freezing appeared to be the coldest in 10 years.

Hundreds of thousands of people gather along the nearly six-mile (10-kilometer) route in Pasadena, where the two-hour parade kicked off. Millions more watch on national television. Organizers at the Pasadena Tournament of Roses, the group that organizes the parade ahead of the Rose Bowl college football game, said they made only small changes to accommodate the weather, such as the tops being up on convertibles carrying grand marshal Earvin ‚ÄúMagic‚Äù Johnson and other VIPs.

Rain forecasts for the Rose Parade, which had been dry for 20 years, grew all week. On Thursday, the National Weather Service issued a flood watch for all California counties and a coastal flood advisory through Sunday afternoon along much of the Pacific Coast near San Francisco.

Meanwhile, residents in the areas hit hardest by last year's devastating Los Angeles-area wildfires were under evacuation warnings.

In New York City, the sun came out ahead of Mayor Zohran Mamdani's inaugural celebration, but other areas of the Northeast and Midwest were hit by an Alberta clipper storm and trailing Arctic front that brought snow squalls and high winds.

Conditions varied widely ‚Äî from snow showers to heavier squalls ‚Äî from Wisconsin through northern Illinois and Michigan and into northern New Jersey, southeastern New York and New England.

About a quarter of flights were delayed out of both San Diego International Airport and Boston Logan, according to the flight tracking website FlightAware.

title: Astrologer Aliza Kelly Reveals 2026 Predictions for Each Zodiac Sign
description: Astrologer Aliza Kelly exclusively shared with E! News what every zodiac sign should expect for 2026: "There‚Äôs a collective push towards passion, communication, and massive advancements."
fullText:

So, hold on tight as we move full speed ahead.

"For everyone, this is a year that demands we make real choices," Aliza noted, "take ourselves seriously, and fight for what we truly believe in. Don't know what you believe in? You'll find out soon enough!"

"In 2026, you‚Äôre learning that fulfillment doesn‚Äôt have to be earned through struggle alone," Aliza shared. "This year invites you to soften, take emotional risks, and reconnect with pleasure. You're allowed to have a little fun, Capricorn! In fact, it would actually be good for you."

The same goes for Aquarius (Jan. 20- Feb. 18), whose year will shift towards "relationships and collaboration."

title: Heavy rain triggers flooding, multiple water rescues across San Diego on New Year‚Äôs Day
description: Heavy rain on New Year's Day caused widespread flooding in San Diego, prompting multiple water rescues and leaving drivers and pedestrians trapped in fast-moving water.
fullText:
SAN DIEGO, Calif. (FOX5/KUSI) ‚Äî Heavy rain soaking San Diego on New Year‚Äôs Day caused widespread flooding and prompted multiple water rescues across the county, as storm runoff overwhelmed roads and drainage systems and left drivers and pedestrians trapped in fast-moving water.

Some of the most severe flooding was reported in¬†Mission Valley, a low-lying area known for flooding during periods of sustained rain. Water remained pooled in parts of the neighborhood hours after the heaviest rainfall, underscoring how quickly conditions deteriorated.

Emergency crews responded to numerous rescue calls throughout the day, including along¬†Fashion Valley Road, where rising floodwaters stranded motorists. In one incident, firefighters rescued one adult and one child from a Jeep that became partially submerged as water levels rose rapidly.

San Diego Fire-Rescue officials said another rescue unfolded nearby at¬†Camino de la Reina¬†and¬†Avenida del Rio, where a man became trapped underneath a bridge as floodwaters surged. Search-and-rescue teams deployed a raft to reach him and safely pulled him out before transporting him to a hospital for medical evaluation.

‚ÄúThis is about as bad as I‚Äôve seen it,‚Äù said Mission Valley resident Steven Shadpour, who noted that flooding has been a recurring issue in the area. ‚ÄúThey told us when I bought the place that Mission Valley is lower elevation, so whenever it rains, it floods down here.‚Äù

Fire officials emphasized that many of the rescues were preventable and urged the public to avoid flooded roads.

Crews also responded to other storm-related emergencies across the county, including a rescue at¬†Lake Hodges, where a woman was swept by floodwaters and later rescued by helicopter.

title: 13 Dirty Truths About Hybrid Cars Everyone Should Know
description: Hybrids promise fuel savings and eco-friendliness, but the full story is more complicated. From costly battery replacements to limited highway efficiency, these vehicles come with trade-offs that many buyers overlook. Their environmental impact starts with resource-heavy battery production and ends with complex recycling challenges. This article breaks down the hidden costs and realities behind the hybrid hype.
fullText:
The narrative around electric vehicles has hit a few speed bumps lately. Despite years of relentless marketing and massive production ramps, the EV takeover hasn't quite materialized as some predicted. Volkswagen and Mercedes-Benz have both extended the life of combustion and hybrid lineups as EV demand has grown more uneven than expected. Volkswagen has said it may keep ICE models longer and even add new ICE offerings without increasing overall investment, by offsetting spending within its existing plan. Mercedes-Benz has also said it will keep upgrading combustion models and has reported higher-than-previously-planned spending on combustion-engine technology alongside delayed electrification targets.

On the other hand, hybrids are experiencing a surge in popularity, with manufacturers competing to offer a dizzying array of options. It's easy to see the appeal: they promise that sweet spot of substantial fuel savings without the existential dread of range anxiety. For many drivers, it seems like the ultimate compromise.

Before you sign on the dotted line for that virtuous hybrid, let's yank back the curtain. Hybrids, for all their supposed eco-cred and practicality, come with their own collection of dirty little secrets.

Like their fully electric counterparts, many hybrids rely on lithium-ion batteries. Extracting the necessary metals, lithium, cobalt, nickel, manganese, and graphite, requires heavy-duty mining operations. Needless to say, these aren't exactly quaint backyard digs. The environmental impact is monumental: think open-pit mining operations that resemble lunar landscapes, carving out vast sections of pristine wilderness.

Consider the thirst: Some commonly cited estimates for brine-based lithium extraction in arid regions put water losses at around ~2‚Äì2.2 million liters per tonne of lithium, but water use varies widely by site and extraction method (brine vs hard-rock; definitions of ‚Äòwater used‚Äô also differ).¬†In arid regions, this puts immense strain on local water supplies, impacting surrounding communities and fragile ecosystems. Beyond the H2O, the chemicals used during extraction and processing are often toxic, posing a significant risk of contaminating soil and groundwater if not meticulously managed. So, that "green" hybrid in your driveway might have a rather large, dirty footprint you never see.

Battery warranty terms vary by brand and market. In the U.S., 8 years is common, and some manufacturers offer longer coverage (for example, Toyota extended hybrid battery coverage to 10 years/150,000 miles for 2020 model-year hybrids). While many last beyond that, there's an undeniable truth: they will eventually degrade to a point where replacement is the only viable option.

And here‚Äôs where your wallet might go into shock. Even though hybrids pack smaller battery packs than pure EVs, they are far from cheap. Hybrid batteries are usually cheaper than full EV packs, but replacements can still be expensive. Many mainstream hybrid battery replacements are often quoted in the roughly $2,000‚Äì$8,000 range depending on the vehicle, battery type, and whether the pack is new or remanufactured. By contrast, full EV battery pack replacements are commonly cited in the $5,000‚Äì$16,000+ range because the packs are much larger.

It‚Äôs not like you‚Äôll be swapping these out in your garage with a ratchet set; this is a specialized job, meaning you‚Äôll also be on the hook for significant labor costs and the often-overlooked expense of proper battery disposal. That "savings at the pump" might just be a future mortgage payment in disguise.

Sure, lithium-ion batteries can be recycled at the end of their life cycle. But "can be" and "is readily done" are two entirely different things. The process is anything but simple. It requires energy-intensive pyrometallurgy or complex hydrometallurgy, far from a casual drop-off at your local recycling center.

Currently, the infrastructure for large-scale, cost-effective lithium-ion battery recycling is still in its infancy. Few companies are willing to invest heavily in a process that‚Äôs both technically challenging and not yet highly profitable. This means it will be a while before someone cracks the code on how to recycle these power packs on a scale large enough to have a significant, positive environmental impact. If you're having a shop replace your high-voltage hybrid battery, Battery handling and end-of-life pathways vary by region and program; recycling exists but can be costly and logistically complex, which can affect what a shop charges for handling.‚Äù (No citation needed; this avoids a hard factual claim you can‚Äôt universally prove).

The hybrid variant of a given car model invariably carries a higher sticker price than its gas-only counterpart. While they are generally more affordable than pure EVs, that upfront premium can put them out of reach for budget-conscious buyers.

Many owners justify this extra expenditure by banking on long-term fuel savings. The harsh reality? It can take several years, or even tens of thousands of miles, to actually break even on that initial investment through fuel savings alone. This is particularly true if you're one of those who replace their car every few years; you might never recoup that premium before the next vehicle purchase.

Opting for a hybrid to "reduce your carbon footprint" is a noble intention, but it assumes you'll be running predominantly on battery power. The inconvenient truth is that most hybrids are still fundamentally internal combustion engines with electric assistance. They do burn gasoline, and they do emit CO2 into the atmosphere.

Factor in the energy-intensive battery manufacturing process and the vehicle's entire lifecycle emissions (LCA), and you might find yourself with a vehicle that, by some metrics, has a higher initial carbon footprint than a conventional ICE car. Your "eco-friendly" commuter still chugs gas, just perhaps with a touch more virtue-signaling.

Sure, some hypercars like the McLaren P1 or Ferrari LaFerrari utilize hybrid technology, but that's for mind-blowing power delivery, not just economy. Your average, everyday hybrid is meticulously engineered to maximize fuel efficiency, typically pairing a modest gas engine with electric motors.

The added weight of the battery pack and electric motor, coupled with the relentless focus on efficiency, sometimes means hybrids are slower to accelerate than their pure ICE counterparts. That extra mass also compromises handling and agility, making them feel less nimble when you try to toss them into a corner. Your hybrid's "sport mode" is often just louder engine noise; don't expect it to win any drag races, unless it's against a kid on a scooter.

When everything is humming along nicely, or if your hybrid is still comfortably under warranty, maintenance costs may be comparable to those of an ICE vehicle. However, that's often still more than the bare-bones servicing requirements of a pure EV.

The real financial hit comes when that warranty expires. Hybrids feature dual powertrains, meaning they combine the complexity of a conventional internal combustion engine (ICE) with high-voltage electric motors, inverters, battery management systems, and specialized cooling systems. If a high-voltage component fails out of warranty, repairs can be astronomically expensive.

Finding an affordable, independent mechanic who possesses the specialized diagnostic tools and training for hybrid systems can also be a significant challenge, often forcing you to return to the pricier dealership service bay. Another hit to your savings that may put that dream car purchase back yet again, good thing you have your hybrid, I guess.

Hybrids are undisputed kings in city driving. Their electric motors excel in stop-and-go traffic, enabling electric-only propulsion at low speeds and recovering energy through regenerative braking. This translates to significantly lower fuel consumption than a gas-only car in urban environments.

However, once you hit the open highway, that advantage rapidly diminishes. A hybrid's fuel consumption often rises drastically, the opposite of what you see in an ICE vehicle. At cruising speeds, the gas engine is predominantly engaged. Because it's usually a smaller, less powerful unit lugging around extra battery weight, it has to work harder than an equivalent, lighter ICE car. Your hybrid's city MPG bragging rights tend to disappear faster than a cheap date on the interstate.

We're constantly fed the narrative that hybrids are inherently more environmentally friendly, but as we've dissected, that's not necessarily true, especially if your driving mostly consists of highway miles. Additionally, if your weekly commute is a short trip to the grocery store and back, paying a significant premium for a hybrid might never yield any financial benefits.

For a hybrid to truly deliver both environmental and economic advantages, you need to cover a substantial amount of miles, predominantly in city driving or stop-and-go traffic, where the electric assist can do its best work. Otherwise, you're just driving a heavier, more complex gas car.

When it comes to pulling heavy loads, traditional gasoline and diesel engines are still the undisputed champions. Even some new EVs, such as the Ford F-150 Lightning, Rivian R1T, and Tesla Cybertruck, are proving their mettle in this arena.

However, for most mainstream hybrids, towing is an afterthought, if it's even allowed. The smaller internal combustion engines are not designed for sustained heavy loads, and the hybrid systems often lack the necessary cooling capacity or robust driveline components. You're clearly not going to be towing more than a Barbie convertible with something like the Prius.

The Toyota Sequoia‚Äôs maximum tow rating is up to 9,520 lbs when properly equipped (Toyota marketing often highlights up to 9,500 lbs, with exact ratings varying by configuration). The Lexus LX Hybrid is rated up to 8,000 lbs. It's good enough for some campers, but most hybrids are coming nowhere near these numbers. Meanwhile, plenty of gas-fueled SUVs and pickups can breezily tow 10,000-plus pounds, giving you a lot more variety of choices to choose from if towing is your priority. But if the Toyota Sequoia is your dream car, you're in luck.

That shiny new hybrid typically comes with a steeper insurance bill than its traditional ICE counterpart. This makes perfect sense when you consider the higher purchase price and the increased technological complexity. Insurance companies aren't charities, after all.

Because hybrid vehicles involve more expensive, specialized components (especially the battery and high-voltage wiring) and require specialized labor for repairs, insurance claims and associated repair costs tend to be higher. Insurance costs vary heavily by model and driver, but some analyses find hybrids average around single-digit percentages higher to insure than comparable gas-only vehicles (one widely cited figure is ~7% higher on average)¬†to insure a hybrid compared to the equivalent gas-only model. That "eco-friendly" car also has an "expensive-to-fix" price tag for the insurance company.

The sophisticated lithium-ion batteries found in hybrids (and EVs) are quite particular about their operating environment. They absolutely despise extreme temperatures. When it‚Äôs scorching hot, it accelerates battery degradation, leading to a permanent loss of capacity over time. Conversely, when the mercury plummets, the battery's chemical reactions slow down, leading to a noticeable reduction in range, power output, and less efficient regenerative braking. What are they, Goldilocks? Apparently, the temperature has to be juuuust right.

Cold temperatures can also significantly impact charging times for plug-in hybrids, forcing the gas engine in standard hybrids to run more frequently and for longer periods to reach optimal operating temperature, thereby directly negating the fuel-saving benefits. Your "advanced" battery is pickier about the weather than your aunt Mildred.

Toyota famously revolutionized the automotive world with the original Prius hybrid, and the technology has evolved dramatically since then. However, the regulatory landscape is shifting. The EU previously set rules aiming for effectively zero-CO‚ÇÇ new car sales from 2035, which would have ruled out most hybrids. However, in December 2025 the European Commission proposed changes that would replace an effective 2035 ICE ‚Äòban‚Äô with a 90% tailpipe CO‚ÇÇ reduction target, potentially allowing some combustion and hybrid-type vehicles to continue under certain conditions due to their reliance on an internal combustion engine.

Meanwhile, pure EVs are advancing at a breakneck pace, and other alternative technologies like e-fuels (synthetic gasoline) and hydrogen fuel cells are gaining traction. It's entirely plausible that hybrids, despite their current popularity, are merely an interim technology, a bridge to a truly fossil-fuel-free future, destined to be phased out as more efficient and advanced solutions mature. Are hybrids the Betamax of the automotive future or a viable long-term solution despite all their flaws? Only time will tell. In that time, we will be crossing our fingers for your wallet.

Like our content? Follow us.
